{{good article}} {{other uses}} {{short description|Island in New York Harbor in New York and New Jersey, United States}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2019}} {{Infobox historic site | name = Ellis Island | image = Arriving at Ellis Island LCCN2014710704.jpg | caption = [[European emigration|European immigrants]] arriving at Ellis Island, 1915 | elevation = {{convert|7|ft|abbr=on}}{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Ellis Island - Hudson County, New Jersey.|url=http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/f?p=150:3:1417806468087358::NO::P3_FID,P3_TITLE:876159,Ellis%20Island|website=|publisher=USGS|accessdate=January 1, 2011}} | location =[[Upper New York Bay]] | coordinates = {{coord|40.699398|-74.041723|region:US-NY_type:landmark_scale:5000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = USA New Jersey Hudson County#New Jersey#New York City#New York#United States | map_caption = | built = 1900 (Main Building) | architect= [[William Alciphron Boring]]
[[Edward Lippincott Tilton]] | architecture= [[Renaissance Revival architecture|Renaissance Revival]] | area = {{convert|27.5|acre|ha}} | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = [[National Park Service]] | website = {{official|https://www.nps.gov/elis}} | designation2 = NMON | designation2_date = May 11, 1965{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=75266|title=Proclamation 3656 - Adding Ellis Island to the Statue of Liberty National Monument|date=April 5, 2010|website=}} | designation2_offname = [[Statue of Liberty National Monument]] | designation3_free1value = | designation3 = NRHP | designation3_offname = [[Statue of Liberty National Monument, Ellis Island and Liberty Island]] | designation3_date = October 15, 1966{{NRISref|2009a}} | designation3_number = 66000058 | designation4 = New Jersey Register of Historic Places | designation4_date = May 27, 1971 | designation4_number = 1535{{cite web|title=New Jersey and National Registers of Historic Places – Hudson County|url=http://www.nj.gov/dep/hpo/1identify/nrsr_lists.htm|publisher=[[New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection]] – Historic Preservation Office|page=|date=|accessdate=August 2, 2014}} | designation5 = NYC Landmark | designation5_date = November 16, 1993{{harvnb|ps=.|Ellis Island Main Building Interior Designation Report|1993}} | designation5_type = District/Individual Interior }} '''Ellis Island''' is a [[Federal government of the United States|federally]] owned [[island]] in [[New York Harbor]] that contains a museum and former [[immigration]] inspection station. As the [[United States]]' busiest immigrant inspection station from 1892 to 1954, it processed approximately 12 million [[Immigration to the United States|immigrants to the country]] through the [[Port of New York and New Jersey]]. Today, it is part of the [[Statue of Liberty National Monument]], accessible to the public only by ferry. The north side of the island hosts the museum of immigration while the south side, including the [[Ellis Island Immigrant Hospital]], is only open to the public through guided tours. In the 19th century, Ellis Island was the site of Fort Gibson, a component of the fortifications of New York Harbor. It later became a [[Magazine (artillery)#Naval magazines|naval magazine]] for storing artillery. The first inspection station opened in 1892 and was destroyed by fire in 1897. The second station opened in 1900 and housed facilities for medical quarantines as well as processing immigrants. After 1924, Ellis Island was used primarily as a detention center. During both [[World War I]] and [[World War II]] its facilities were also used by the United States military to detain prisoners of war. Following the immigration station's closure, the buildings languished for several years until they partially reopened in 1976. The main building and adjacent structures were completely renovated in 1990. The {{convert|27.5|acre|ha|abbr=|adj=on}} island was greatly expanded by [[land reclamation]] between the late 1890s and the 1930s. Jurisdictional disputes between [[New Jersey]] and [[New York (state)|New York]] persisted until 1998, when the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] ruled in ''[[New Jersey v. New York]]'' that the {{convert|3.3|acre}} that comprise the original island and its environs are part of New York and that almost all of the reclaimed land is part of New Jersey. ==Geography and access== Ellis Island is in [[Upper New York Bay]] within [[New York Harbor]], east of [[Liberty State Park]] and north of [[Liberty Island]]. While most of the island is in [[Jersey City, New Jersey]], a small section is an [[exclave]] of [[New York City]].{{Cite book|publisher=Hagstrom Map Company, Inc|isbn=978-0-88097-763-0|title=Hudson County New Jersey Street Map|year=2010}}{{cite journal|first=Richard G.|last=Castagna|first2=Lawrence L.|last2=Thornton|first3=John M.|last3=Tyrawski|title=GIS and Coastal Boundary Disputes: Where is Ellis Island?|publisher=ESRI|url=http://proceedings.esri.com/library/userconf/proc99/proceed/papers/pap138/p138.htm|accessdate=November 17, 2013|quote=The New York portion of Ellis Island is landlocked, enclaved within New Jersey's territory.|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018003341/http://proceedings.esri.com/library/userconf/proc99/proceed/papers/pap138/p138.htm|archivedate=October 18, 2014}}The island has a land area of {{convert|27.5|acre|ha}}, much of which is from [[land reclamation]]. The {{convert|2.74|acre|adj=on}} natural island and contiguous areas comprise {{convert|3.3|acre}} within New York, and are located on the northern portion of the present-day island.{{Cite web|url=https://www.libertyellisfoundation.org/ellis-island-history|title=Ellis Island History - The Statue of Liberty & Ellis Island|website=www.libertyellisfoundation.org|access-date=2020-02-07}} The artificial land is part of New Jersey.{{cite web|first=Joan|last=Biskupic|title=N.J. Wins Claim to Most of Ellis Island|date=May 27, 1998|work=[[The Washington Post]]|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/national/longterm/supcourt/stories/wpellis052798.htm|accessdate=July 12, 2014}} The island has been owned and administered by the [[federal government of the United States]] since 1808 and operated by the National Park Service since 1965.{{cite web|title=Frequently asked questions|work=Ellis Island Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument|publisher=National Park Service|url=http://www.nps.gov/elis/faqs.htm|accessdate=November 18, 2013}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.libertyellisfoundation.org/ellis-timeline|title=The Statue of Liberty & Ellis Island|website=www.libertyellisfoundation.org|access-date=2020-02-07}} === Land expansion === Initially, much of the Upper New York Bay's western shore consisted of large [[Mudflat|tidal flats]] with vast [[Oyster|oyster beds]], which were a major source of food for the Lenape. Ellis Island was one of three "Oyster Islands," the other two being [[Liberty Island]] and the now-destroyed [[Black Tom explosion#Black Tom Island|Black Tom Island]].{{cite book|author=New Jersey. Legislature. Senate|title=Journal of the ... Senate of the State of New Jersey: Being the ... Session of the Legislature|year=1860|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wm1MAAAAYAAJ | access-date=June 11, 2019|page=}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nwYl-7DhMvcC&pg=PA35|title=The Big Oyster: History on the Half Shell|last=Kurlansky|first=Mark|publisher=Random House Publishing Group|year=2007|isbn=978-1-58836-591-0|page=35|access-date=June 4, 2019}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/01/books/before-there-were-bagels-new-york-had-the-oyster.html|title=Before There Were Bagels, New York Had the Oyster|last=Grimes|first=William|date=February 1, 2006|website=The New York Times|access-date=June 3, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} In the late 19th century, the federal government began expanding the island by [[land reclamation]] to accommodate its immigration station, and the expansions continued until 1934.{{cite web|url=http://www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2017882211/|title=Ellis Island, New Jersey, in Upper New York Bay, was the gateway for over 12 million immigrants to the United States as the nation's busiest immigrant inspection station for over sixty years from 1892 until 1954|date=August 24, 2017|website=Home | Library of Congress|access-date=July 14, 2019}} The fill was acquired from the ballast of ships, as well as material excavated from the [[Early history of the IRT subway|first line]] of the [[New York City Subway]].{{cite web|title=Fact Sheet: Statue of Liberty NM -- Ellis Island|website=National Parks of New York Harbor (U.S. National Park Service)|date=May 11, 1965|url=https://www.nps.gov/npnh/learn/news/fact-sheet-elis.htm | access-date=May 1, 2019}} It also came from the [[Rail yard|railyards]] of the [[Lehigh Valley Railroad]] and the [[Central Railroad of New Jersey]]. It eventually obliterated the oyster beds, engulfed one of the Oyster Islands, and brought the shoreline much closer to the others.{{cite court|url=http://supreme.justia.com/us/209/473/case.html|litigants=Central R. Co. of New Jersey v. Jersey City|vol=209 |reporter=U.S. |opinion=473 |date=1908}} The current island is shaped like a "C", with two landmasses of equal size on the northeastern and southwestern sides, separated by what was formerly a ferry pier. It was originally three separate islands. The current north side, formerly called island 1, contains the original island and the fill around it. The current south side was composed of island 2, created in 1899, and island 3, created in 1906. Two eastward-facing ferry docks separated the three numbered landmasses.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/elis/learn/education/upload/9-12-Ellis-Island-Map.pdf|title=Structural Development of Ellis Island, 1890-1935|publisher=National Park Service|access-date=June 3, 2019}} The fill was retained with a system of wood piles and cribbing, and later encased with more than 7,700 linear feet of concrete and granite sea wall. It was placed atop either wood piles, cribbing, or submerged bags of concrete. In the 1920s, the second ferry basin between islands 2 and 3 was infilled to create the great lawn, forming the current south side of Ellis Island. As part of the project, a concrete and granite seawall was built to connect the tip of these landmasses.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=73}} ===State sovereignty dispute=== [[File:EllisIslandMapOSM.png|thumb|left|A map showing the territorial division of acreage]] The circumstances which led to an exclave of New York being located within New Jersey began in the colonial era, after the British takeover of [[New Netherland]] in 1664. A clause in the colonial land grant outlined the territory that the proprietors of [[New Jersey]] would receive as being "westward of Long Island, and Manhitas Island and bounded on the east part by the main sea, and part by Hudson's river."See: *{{cite web|url=http://avalon.law.yale.edu/17th_century/nj01.asp|title=The Federal and State constitutions, colonial charters, and other organic laws of the state[s], territories, and colonies now or heretofore forming the United States of America /compiled and edited under the Act of Congress of June 30, 1906|date=December 18, 1998}} *{{cite book | author=United States Congress | title=American State Papers: Documents, Legislative and Executive, of the Congress of the United States | publisher=Gales and Seaton | series=American State Papers: Documents, Legislative and Executive, of the Congress of the United States | issue=v. 20 | year=1832 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rvA1AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA479 | access-date=February 12, 2020 | page=479}} *{{cite book | title=Historical Magazine: And Notes and Queries Concerning the Antiquities, History, and Biography of America | publisher=H. B. Dawson | year=1867 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JW4-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA136 | access-date=February 12, 2020 | page=136}}{{cite book | last=Gannett | first=H. | author2=Geological Survey (U.S.) | title=Boundaries of the United States and of the Several States and Territories: With an Outline of the History of All Important Changes of Territory | publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office | series=Bulletin of the United States Geological Survey | year=1900 | url=https://archive.org/details/cihm_16885 | page=[https://archive.org/details/cihm_16885/page/n136 80] | access-date=February 12, 2020 }}{{rp|82}} As early as 1804, attempts were made to resolve the status of the state line.{{Cite web|title=Ellis Island Its Legal Status|publisher=General Services Administration Office of General Counsel|date=February 28, 1963|url=http://www.nps.gov/history/history/online_books/stli/ellis_island_legal.pdf|accessdate=September 25, 2010|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090831182303/http://www.nps.gov/history/history/online_books/stli/ellis_island_legal.pdf|archivedate=August 31, 2009}} The [[City of New York]] claimed the right to regulate trade on all waters. This was contested in ''[[Gibbons v. Ogden]]'', which decided that the regulation of interstate commerce fell under the authority of the federal government, thus influencing competition in the newly developing steam ferry service in [[New York Harbor]].{{ussc|name=Gibbons v. Ogden|link=|volume=22|page=1|pin=|year=1824|reporter=Wheat.|reporter-volume=9}} In 1830, New Jersey planned to bring suit to clarify the border, but the case was never heard.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/27/nyregion/ellis-island-verdict-ruling-high-court-gives-new-jersey-most-ellis-island.html|title=The Ellis Island Verdict: The Ruling; High Court Gives New Jersey Most of Ellis Island|last=Greenhouse|first=Linda|date=May 27, 1998|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 6, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The matter was resolved with a compact between the states, ratified by [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]] in 1834. This set the boundary line at the middle of the Hudson River and New York Harbor; however, New York was guaranteed "exclusive jurisdiction of and over all the waters of Hudson River lying west of Manhattan and to the south of the mouth of [[Spuyten Duyvil Creek|Spuytenduyvil Creek]]; and of and over the lands covered by the said waters, to the low-water mark on the New Jersey shore."{{rp|78–79}} This solution was later confirmed in other cases by the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]].{{cite court |litigants=Application of Devoe Manufacturing Company for a Writ of Prohibition/Opinion of the Court |vol=108 |reporter=U.S. |opinion=401 |pinpoint= |court= |date=1882 |url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Application_of_Devoe_Manufacuring_Company_for_a_Writ_of_Prohibition/Opinion_of_the_Court |accessdate= |quote=}}{{Cite journal|title=Ellis Island Its Legal Status|publisher=General Services Administration Office of General Counsel|date=February 11, 1963|url=http://www.nps.gov/history/history/online_books/stli/ellis_island_legal.pdf|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120804212618/http://www.nps.gov/history/history/online_books/stli/ellis_island_legal.pdf|archivedate=August 4, 2012}}{{Cite news|last=Greenhouse|first=Linda|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/13/nyregion/skeptical-high-court-hears-case-over-pride-and-acreage-on-ellis-i.html|title=Skeptical High Court Hears Case Over Pride and Acreage on Ellis I.|date=1998-01-13|work=The New York Times|access-date=2020-02-11|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} New Jersey contended that the artificial portions of the island were part of New Jersey, since they were outside New York's border. In 1956, after the closure of the U.S. immigration station two years prior, the then-[[Mayor of Jersey City]], [[Bernard J. Berry]], commandeered a U.S. Coast Guard cutter and led a contingent of New Jersey officials on an expedition to claim the island.{{cite magazine|last=Logan|first=Andy|author2=McCarten, John|title=Invasion from Jersey|magazine=The New Yorker|date=January 14, 1956|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/1956/01/14/1956_01_14_019_TNY_CARDS_000252353|accessdate=February 14, 2011}} Jurisdictional disputes reemerged in the 1980s with the renovation of Ellis Island,{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32504422/|title=A tale of two cities: Both claim Ellis Island|last=Moritz|first=Owen|date=June 20, 1982|work=New York Daily News|access-date=June 5, 2019|pages=75|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} and then again in the 1990s with the proposed redevelopment of the south side.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32246752/|title=Ellis Island mostly in N.J.|last=Seitz|first=Sharon|date=April 2, 1997|work=Central New Jersey Home News|pages=[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32246752/ 1], [https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32246787/ 6]|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} New Jersey sued in 1997, and subsequently the border was redrawn using [[geographic information science]] data.{{cite book|last=Cho|first=G.|title=Geographic Information Science: Mastering the Legal Issues|publisher=Wiley|series=Mastering GIS: Technol, Applications & Mgmnt|year=2005|isbn=978-0-470-01355-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-nGK3Lr-DqQC&pg=PA37 | access-date=June 11, 2019|page=37}} The lawsuit was escalated to the Supreme Court, which ruled in ''[[New Jersey v. New York]]'' {{Ussc|523|767|1998|el=no}} that all of the infilled portions of the island were part of New Jersey.{{Cite court|litigants=New Jersey v. New York|court=|reporter=U.S.|vol=523|opinion=767|pinpoint=|date=1998|url=https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/523/767/|quote=New Jersey has sovereign authority over the filled land added to the original Island.}}{{cite news|title=Court rules Ellis Island is mostly in New Jersey|last=Brogan|first=Pamela|date=May 27, 1998|work=Courier-Post|last2=Gannett News Service|location=Camden, NJ|pages=[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32518085/ 1], [https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32518184/ 4]|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} This caused several immediate instances of confusion, as some buildings straddled the interstate border. The ruling had no effect on the status of [[Liberty Island]].{{cite web|url=http://www.state.nj.us/dep/njgs/geodata/historicfill/jersey.pdf|title= Historic Fill Of The Jersey City Quadrangle Historic Fill Map HFM-53|publisher=New State Department of Environmental Protection|accessdate=August 31, 2014|year=2004}}{{cite web|url=http://www.njspls.org/?130|title=Is Liberty a Jersey Girl|date=February 4, 2014|accessdate=February 10, 2020|publisher=New Jersey Society of Professional Land Surveyors}} Though the island remained in federal ownership after the lawsuit, New Jersey and New York agreed to share jurisdiction over the land itself. Neither state would take any fiscal or physical responsibility for the maintenance, preservation, or improvement of any of the historic properties, and each state would have jurisdiction over its respective land areas. Jersey City and New York City then gave separate tax lot numbers to their respective claims.{{efn|The boundaries remain the same as today.{{cite web|title=Ellis Island Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument (U.S. National Park Service)|website=Maps|date=March 9, 2016|url=https://www.nps.gov/elis/planyourvisit/maps.htm | access-date=June 3, 2019}} The New York side of the island is [[Tax assessment|assessed]] as Manhattan Block 1, Lot 201,{{cite web|title=An inaugural choice: Will N.J. governor's gala really be in New York?|website=silive.com|date=December 21, 2013|url=https://www.silive.com/opinion/2013/12/an_inaugural_choice_will_nj_go.html | access-date=June 3, 2019|quote=After the 1998 court event, both states agreed to share jurisdiction, even though the islands remain a wholly federal property. To cement those claims, New York assigned Ellis Island the tax designation of Block 1, Lot 201. The state of New Jersey gave the place its own tax number.}}{{harvnb|ps=.|Robins|Urbanelli|1993|p=6}} while the portion of the island in New Jersey is assessed as Jersey City Block 21603, Lot 1.{{cite web|title=Tax Map Viewer - Jersey City|website=hostedfiles.civilsolutions.biz|url=http://hostedfiles.civilsolutions.biz/jerseycity/taxmaps/index.htm | access-date=June 3, 2019|at=Sheet 216}}}} ===Public access=== Two ferry slips are located on the northern side of the basin that bisects Ellis Island. No charge is made for entrance to the Statue of Liberty National Monument, but there is a cost for the ferry service that all visitors must use.{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/stli/planyourvisit/fees.htm|title=Fees & Passes|date=May 20, 2019|website=Statue Of Liberty National Monument (U.S. National Park Service)|access-date=June 16, 2019}} A concession was granted in 2007 to [[Statue Cruises]] to operate the transportation and ticketing facilities, replacing [[Circle Line Downtown|Circle Line]], which had operated the service since 1953.{{cite web | last=Ramirez | first=Anthony | title=Circle Line Loses Pact for Ferries to Liberty Island | website=The New York Times | date=June 29, 2007 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/29/nyregion/29ferry.html | access-date=June 16, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The ferries travel from [[Liberty State Park]] in [[Jersey City, New Jersey|Jersey City]] and [[The Battery (Manhattan)|the Battery]] in [[Lower Manhattan]].{{cite web |publisher=National Park Service |title=NPS: Liberty and Ellis Island ferry map |work=Ferry Map |url=http://www.nps.gov/stli/planyourvisit/ferry-system-map.htm |accessdate=October 20, 2011}} The NPS also offers guided public tours of the south side as part of the "Hard Hat Tour".{{Cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/elis/learn/news/south-side-tours-begin.htm|title=Unrestored Ellis Island Buildings Opening for the First Time in 60 Years - Ellis Island Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument (U.S. National Park Service)|date=September 15, 2014|website=www.nps.gov|language=en|access-date=June 16, 2019}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.saveellisisland.org/tour/hard-hat-tours.html|title=Hard Hat Tours|website=www.saveellisisland.org|access-date=June 16, 2019}} A bridge to Liberty State Park was built in 1986 for transporting materials and personnel during the island's late-1980s restoration. Originally slated to be torn down in 1992,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/04/29/nyregion/linking-jersey-city-to-ellis-i-bridge-with-a-brief-life-span.html|title=Linking Jersey City to Ellis I., Bridge with a Brief Life Span|last=Norman|first=Michael|date=April 29, 1986|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 8, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} it remained after construction was complete.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/12/nyregion/house-action-dooms-plan-for-a-bridge-to-ellis-island.html|title=House Action Dooms Plan For a Bridge to Ellis Island|last=MacFarquhar|first=Neil|date=May 12, 1995|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 8, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} It is not open to the public. The city of New York and the island's private ferry operator have opposed proposals to use it or replace it with a pedestrian bridge,{{cite book|last=Low|first=Setha|last2=Taplin|first2=Dana|last3=Scheld|first3=Suzanne|title=Rethinking Urban Parks: Public Space and Cultural Diversity|publisher=University of Texas Press|year=2009|isbn=978-0-292-77821-4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cUhYBCSAYIEC | access-date=June 3, 2019|at=chapter 4}} and a 1995 proposal for a new pedestrian bridge to New Jersey was voted down in the [[United States House of Representatives]]. The bridge is not strong enough to be classified as a permanent bridge, and any action to convert it into a pedestrian passageway would require renovations.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/27/nyregion/on-the-waterfront-a-bridge-to-ellis-island-what-about-one-that-s-there.html|title=On the Waterfront; A Bridge to Ellis Island? What About One That's There?|last=Stemer|first=Rosalie|date=August 27, 1995|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 8, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} == History == === Precolonial and colonial use === [[File:Ellis island air photo.jpg|thumb|Aerial view]] The present-day Ellis Island was created by retreating glaciers at the end of the [[Wisconsin glaciation]] about 15,000 years ago. The island was described as a "hummock along a plain fronting the west side of the Hudson River estuary,"{{harvnb|Stakely|2003|ps=.|p=13}} and when the glaciers melted, the water of the [[Upper New York Bay]] surrounded the mass. The native [[Mohegan people|Mohegan]] name for the island was "Kioshk", meaning "Gull Island",{{harvnb|Stakely|2003|ps=.|p=21}}{{cite web|url=https://daily.jstor.org/the-curious-history-of-ellis-island/|title=The Curious History of Ellis Island|date=December 1, 2016|website=JSTOR Daily|access-date=June 4, 2019}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.amny.com/news/ellis-island-facts-about-the-immigration-center-and-beyond-1.12781876|title=Fascinating facts about Ellis Island|date=December 20, 2016|website=am New York|language=en|access-date=June 4, 2019}} in reference to Ellis Island's former large population of [[seagull]]s. Kioshk was composed mostly of marshy, brackish lowlands that disappeared underwater at [[Tide|high tide]]. The Native American tribes who lived nearby are presumed to have been [[hunter-gatherer]]s who used the island to hunt for fish and oysters, as well as to build transient hunting and fishing communities there.{{harvnb|ps=.|Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island EIS|2005|p=67}}{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=14}} It is unlikely that the Native Americans established permanent settlements on Kioshk, since the island would have been submerged at high tide. In 1630, the Dutch bought Kioshk as a gift for [[Michael Reyniersz Pauw]],{{efn|Also Paaw or Paauw}} who had helped found [[New Netherland]].{{harvnb|Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island EIS|2005|ps=.|p=3}}{{harvnb|Historic Structure Report: The Main Building|1988|ps=.|p=10}} When the Dutch settled the area as part of [[New Netherland]], the three islands in Upper New York Bay—Liberty, Black Tom, and Ellis Islands—were given the name [[Oyster]] Islands, alluding to the large oyster population nearby. The present-day Ellis Island was thus called "Little Oyster Island",{{harvnb|Robins|Urbanelli|1993|ps=.|p=10}} a name that persisted through at least the early 1900s.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NGI9AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA5|title=The Oyster Industry of New Jersey|last=Stainsby|first=W.|publisher=Unionist-Gazette Association, State Printers, Somerville, N.J.|year=1902|series=Monographs on New Jersey's industries|page=5|access-date=June 4, 2019}}{{efn|The name "Little Oyster Island" persisted even though Ellis Island was larger than the former Black Tom Island. By comparison, the comparatively large Liberty Island was called "Great Oyster Island".{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/10/nyregion/new-york-today-the-big-oyster.html|title=New York Today: The Big Oyster|last=Levine|first=Alexandra S.|date=May 10, 2016|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 4, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}}} Little Oyster Island was then sold to Captain William Dyre {{Circa|1674}},{{efn|The sale may have happened as late as 1680.}} then to Thomas Lloyd on April 23, 1686.{{harvnb|ps=.|Moreno|2004|p=xii}} The island was then sold several more times, including to Enoch and Mary Story. During colonial times, Little Oyster Island became a popular spot for hosting oyster roasts, picnics, and clambakes because of its rich oyster beds. Evidence of recreational uses on the island was visible by the mid-18th century with the addition of commercial buildings to the northeast shore.{{Cite book|title=Ellis Island Coming to the Land of Liberty|last=Bial|first=Raymond|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|year=2009|isbn=978-0-618-99943-9|location=215 Park Avenue South, New York, New York 10003|pages=[https://archive.org/details/ellisislandcomin0000bial/page/12 12]|url=https://archive.org/details/ellisislandcomin0000bial/page/12}} By the 1760s, Little Oyster Island became a public execution site for pirates, with executions occurring at one tree in particular, the "Gibbet Tree".{{cite web|url=http://www.libertyellisfoundation.org/ellis-timeline#1900|title=Ellis Island Timeline|date=May 20, 2015|website=The Statue of Liberty & Ellis Island Foundation|access-date=December 11, 2019}} However, there is scant evidence that this was common practice. Little Oyster Island was acquired by Samuel Ellis, a colonial New Yorker and merchant possibly from [[Wales]], in 1774.{{harvnb|ps=.|Moreno|2004|p=72}} He unsuccessfully attempted to sell the island nine years later.{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/marketbookconta00voegoog|title=The Market Book. Containing a Historical Account of the Public Markets in the Cities of New York, Boston, Philadelphia, and Brooklyn. With a Brief Description of Every Article of Human Food Sold Therein|publisher=Author|last=De Voe|first=T.F.|year=1862|page=[https://archive.org/details/marketbookconta00voegoog/page/n321 315]|access-date=June 4, 2019}}{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=16}} Ellis died in 1794,{{Cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/elis/learn/historyculture/ellis-island-chronology.htm|title=Ellis Island Chronology - Ellis Island Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument (U.S. National Park Service)|website=www.nps.gov|language=en|access-date=June 4, 2019}} and as per his will, the ownership of Ellis Island passed to his daughter Catherine Westervelt's unborn son, who was also named Samuel. When the junior Samuel died shortly after birth, ownership passed to the senior Samuel's other two daughters, Elizabeth Ryerson and Rachel Cooder. === Military use and Fort Gibson === Ellis Island was also used by the military for almost 80 years.{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/elis/learn/historyculture/places_colonial_early_american.htm|title=Colonial and Early American New York|date=February 26, 2015|website=Ellis Island Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument (U.S. National Park Service)|access-date=June 4, 2019}} By the mid-1790s, as a result of the United States' increased military tensions with Britain and France, a U.S. congressional committee drew a map of possible locations for the [[First System]] of fortifications to protect major American urban centers such as New York Harbor.{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/stream/culturallandscap10nati#page/n1/mode/2up|title=Cultural Landscape Report for Governors Island National Monument|last=Novak|first=Liza|date=July 21, 2010|publisher=[[United States Department of the Interior]], [[National Park Service]]|page=30|via=Internet Archive}}{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/governorsisland00smitgoog|title=Governors Island, its military history under three flags, 1637-1913|last=Smith|first=Edmund Banks|date=1913|publisher=Valentine's Manual New York}}{{Rp|54}} A small part of Ellis Island from “the soil from high to low waters mark around Ellis’s Island" was owned by the city. On April 21, 1794, the city deeded that land to the state for public defense purposes.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XapGAQAAIAAJ|title=United States Congressional serial set|author=United States Congress|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office|year=1963|isbn=|series=United States Congressional serial set|location=|page=|pages=|language=en|access-date=June 4, 2019|issue=v. 12532}} The following year, the state allotted $100,000 for fortifications on Bedloe's, Ellis, and [[Governors Island]]s, as well as the construction of [[Castle Clinton|Castle Garden]] (now Castle Clinton{{cite web | title=History & Culture | website=Castle Clinton National Monument (U.S. National Park Service) | date=March 24, 2010 | url=https://www.nps.gov/cacl/learn/historyculture/index.htm | access-date=January 6, 2020}}) along [[The Battery (Manhattan)|the Battery]] on Manhattan island. Batteries and magazines were built on Ellis Island in preparation for a war.{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/americanstatepap_e01unit|title=American State Papers: Documents, Legislative and Executive, of the Congress of the United States|author=United States. Congress|publisher=Gales and Seaton|year=1832|series=American State Papers: Documents, Legislative and Executive, of the Congress of the United States|page=[https://archive.org/details/americanstatepap_e01unit/page/193 193]|access-date=June 4, 2019|issue=v. 1; v. 5; v. 16}} A [[jetty]] was added to the northwestern extremity of the island, possibly from soil excavated from an inlet at the northeastern corner; the inlet was infilled by 1813. Though the military threat never materialized, further preparations were spurred by another possibility of war with France in the late 1790s;{{harvnb|ps=.|Historic Structure Report: The Main Building|1988|p=11}} these new preparations were supervised by [[Ebenezer Stevens]].{{Rp|153–154}} The military conflict also failed to occur, and by 1805, the fort had become rundown.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=18}} Stevens, who observed that the Ellis family still owned most of the island, suggested selling off the land to the federal government. Samuel Ryerson, one of Samuel Ellis's grandsons, deeded the island to John A. Berry in 1806.{{harvnb|ps=.|Moreno|2004|p=xxii}} The remaining portion of the island was acquired by condemnation the next year, and it was ceded to the United States on June 30, 1808, for $10,000.{{Cite web|last=Logan|first=Andy|authorlink=|author2=McCarten, John|title=Invasion from Jersey|work=Talk of the Town|publisher=The New Yorker|date=January 14, 1956|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/1956/01/14/1956_01_14_019_TNY_CARDS_000252353|format=|doi=|accessdate=February 14, 2011}} Lieutenant Colonel [[Jonathan Williams (engineer)|Jonathan Williams]], placed in charge of New York Harbor defenses in the early 1800s, proposed several new fortifications around the harbor as part of the [[Seacoast defense in the United States#Second system|Second System]] of fortifications. The new fortifications included increased firepower and improved weaponry.{{Rp|55–56}} The [[United States Department of War|War Department]] established a circular stone 14-gun [[Artillery battery|battery]], a mortar battery (possibly of six mortars), [[Magazine (artillery)|magazine]], and [[barracks]].{{cite book|last1=Wade|first1=Arthur P.|title=Artillerists and Engineers: The Beginnings of American Seacoast Fortifications, 1794-1815|publisher=CDSG Press|year=2011|page=243|isbn=978-0-9748167-2-2}}{{cite web|title=Fort Gibson|website=New York Division of Military and Naval Affairs|date=October 1, 2002|url=http://dmna.state.ny.us/forts/fortsE_L/gibsonFort.htm | access-date=June 3, 2019}}{{cite web|title=New York Forts: page 6|website=North American Forts|url=http://www.northamericanforts.com/East/nycity2.html#gibson | access-date=June 3, 2019}} The fort was initially called Crown Fort, but by the end of the [[War of 1812]] the battery was named Fort Gibson, in honor of Colonel James Gibson of the 4th Regiment of Riflemen, who was killed in the war during the [[Siege of Fort Erie]].{{cite book|last=Roberts|first=Robert B.|authorlink=|title=Encyclopedia of Historic Forts: The Military, Pioneer, and Trading Posts of the United States|publisher=Macmillan|year=1988|pages=554–555|location=New York|isbn=978-0-02-926880-3}} The fort was not used in combat during the war, and instead served as a barracks for the [[11th Infantry Regiment (United States)#War of 1812|11th Regiment]], as well as a jail for British prisoners of war. [[File:(King1893NYC) pg087 ELLIS-ISLAND IMMIGRANT STATION.jpg|thumb|right|Ellis Island buildings circa 1893]] Immediately after the end of the War of 1812, Fort Gibson was largely used as a recruiting depot. The fort went into decline due to under-utilization, and it was being jointly administered by the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] and [[United States Navy|Navy]] by the mid-1830s. Around this time, in 1834, the extant portions of Ellis Island was declared to be an exclave of New York within the waters of New Jersey. The era of joint administration was short-lived: the Army took over the fort's administration in 1841, demoted the fort to an artillery battery, and stopped [[garrison]]ing the fort, leaving a small Navy guard outside the magazine. By 1854, Battery Gibson contained an 11-gun battery, three naval magazines, a short railroad line, and several auxiliary structures such as a cookhouse, gun carriage house, and officers' quarters.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=19}} The Army continued to maintain the fort until 1860, when it abandoned the weapons at Battery Gibson. The artillery magazine was expanded in 1861, during the [[American Civil War]], and part of the parapet was removed. At the end of the Civil War, the fort declined again, this time to an extent that the weaponry was rendered unusable. Through the 1870s, the Navy built additional buildings for its artillery magazine on Ellis Island,{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=20}} eventually constructing 11 buildings in total.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1889/10/20/archives/an-island-of-explosives-where-the-navy-stores-its-gunpowder-big.html|title=An Island of Explosives; Where the Navy Stores Its Gunpowder. Big Magazines on Ellis Island in New-York Bay--Precautions Against Accidental Explosions.|date=October 20, 1889|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 5, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Complaints about the island's magazines started to form, and by the 1870s, ''The New York Sun'' was publishing "alarming reports" about the magazines. The guns were ordered removed in 1881, and the island passed under the complete control of the Navy's Bureau of Ordnance.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1886/05/09/archives/the-story-of-ellis-island-interesting-incidents-of-life-in-a.html|title=The Story of Ellis Island.; Interesting Incidents of Life in a Government Powder Magazine.|date=May 9, 1886|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 5, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} === First immigration station === [[File:Ellis Island First Bldg Burnt 15-June-1897.jpg|thumb|right|First Ellis Island Immigrant Station, built in 1892 and destroyed 1897]]The Army had unsuccessfully attempted to use Ellis Island "for the convalescence for immigrants" as early as 1847. Across New York Harbor, Castle Clinton had been used as an immigration station since 1855, processing more than eight million immigrants during that time.{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/elis/learn/historyculture/places_immigration.htm|title=Immigration|date=December 17, 1900|website=Ellis Island Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument (U.S. National Park Service)|access-date=June 5, 2019}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nycgovparks.org/parks/battery-park/history|title=The Battery Highlights : NYC Parks|date=June 26, 1939|website=New York City Department of Parks & Recreation|access-date=June 5, 2019}} The individual states had their own varying immigration laws until 1875, but the federal government regarded Castle Clinton as having "varied charges of mismanagement, abuse of immigrants, and evasion of the laws", and as such, wanted it to be completely replaced.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=27}} The federal government assumed control of immigration in early 1890 and commissioned a study to determine the best place for the new immigration station in New York Harbor. Among members of the [[United States Congress]], there were disputes about whether to build the station on Ellis, Governors, or Liberty Islands. Initially, Liberty Island was selected as the site for the immigration station, but due to opposition for immigration stations on both Liberty and Governors Islands, the committee eventually decided to build the station on Ellis Island.{{Efn|The opposition to an immigration station on Liberty Island stemmed from the fact that the [[Statue of Liberty]] would be built there, while Governors Island was still an active military fort.}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1890/03/25/archives/in-favor-of-ellis-island-uncle-sam-and-the-immigration-problem-the.html|title=In Favor of Ellis Island; Uncle Sam and the Immigration Problem|date=March 25, 1890|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 5, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Since Castle Clinton's lease was about to expire, Congress approved a bill to build an immigration station on Ellis Island.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1187989/|title=Ellis Island for the Immigrants|last=|first=|date=April 6, 1890|work=Brooklyn Daily Eagle|access-date=June 5, 2019|pages=1|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} On April 11, 1890, the federal government ordered the magazine at Ellis Island be torn down to make way for the U.S.'s first federal immigration station at the site. The [[United States Department of the Treasury|Department of the Treasury]], which was in charge of constructing federal buildings in the U.S.,{{harvnb|ps=.|Robins|Urbanelli|1993|p=14}} officially took control of the island that May 24.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=28}} Congress initially allotted $75,000 to construct the station and later doubled that appropriation. While the building was under construction, the Barge Office at the Battery was used for immigrant processing.{{harvnb|ps=.|Historic Structure Report: The Main Building|1988|p=12}} During construction, most of the old Battery Gibson buildings were demolished, and Ellis Island's land size was almost doubled to {{Convert|6|acre|ha|abbr=}}.{{cite journal|last=Ralph|first=Julian|year=1891|title=Landing the Immigrant|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zkJaAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA821|journal=Harper's Weekly|series=Library of American civilization|issue=v. 35|page=821|access-date=June 5, 2019}} The main structure was a two-story structure of [[Pinus palustris|Georgia Pine]],{{harvnb|ps=.|Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island EIS|2005|p=5}} which was described in ''[[Harper's Weekly]]'' as "a latterday watering place hotel" measuring {{Convert|400|by|150|ft|m|abbr=}}. Its outbuildings included a hospital, detention building, laundry building, and utility plant that were all made of wood. Some of the former stone magazine structures were reused for utilities and offices. Additionally, a [[ferry slip]] with [[Breakwater (structure)|breakwater]] was built to the south of Ellis Island. Following further expansion, the island measured {{Convert|11|acre|ha|abbr=}} by the end of 1892. The station opened on January 1, 1892,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1892/01/02/archives/landed-on-ellis-island-new-immigration-buildings-opened-yesterday-a.html|title=Landed on Ellis Island; New Immigration Buildings Opened Yesterday|date=January 2, 1892|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 5, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24069185/newspaper_article_about_the_first_group/|title=The First to Land|date=January 2, 1892|work=Democrat and Chronicle|access-date=June 5, 2019|location=Rochester, NY|pages=1|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} and its first immigrant was [[Annie Moore (immigrant)|Annie Moore]], a 17-year-old girl from [[Cork (city)|Cork]], Ireland, who was traveling with her two brothers to meet their parents in the U.S.{{cite web|url=http://www.ellisisland.org/search/passRecord.asp?pID=604534030002&MID=02806987110023700416& |title=Passenger Record: Annie Moore|work=The Statue of Liberty – Ellis Island Foundation|access-date=April 24, 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5194366/|title=First Foot on Ellis Island|date=January 2, 1892|work=New York Sun|access-date=June 5, 2019|pages=2|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} On the first day, almost 700 immigrants passed over the docks. Over the next year, over 400,000 immigrants were processed at the station.{{Efn|The cited figures may run as high as 480,000.}}{{harvnb|ps=.|Historic Structure Report: The Main Building|1988|p=13}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1893/01/01/archives/immigrants-of-a-year-some-statistics-from-landing-agent-moore-of.html|title=Immigrants of a Year.; Some Statistics from Landing Agent Moore of Ellis Island|date=January 1, 1893|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 6, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The processing procedure included a [[Ellis Island#Inspection lines|series of medical and mental inspection lines]], and through this process, some 1% of potential immigrants were deported.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20781025/|title=Gateway of the Continent|date=January 5, 1896|work=Brooklyn Daily Eagle|access-date=June 5, 2019|pages=9|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} Additional building improvements took place throughout the mid-1890s,{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=29}}{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32294070/|title=Ellis Island's Crowds|last=|first=|date=April 17, 1896|work=Brooklyn Daily Eagle|access-date=June 5, 2019|pages=7|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1896/08/20/archives/improvements-at-ellis-island.html|title=Improvements at Ellis Island|date=August 20, 1896|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 6, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} and Ellis Island was expanded to {{Convert|14|acre|ha|abbr=}} by 1896. The last improvements, which entailed the installation of underwater telephone and telegraph cables to Governors Island, were completed in early June 1897. On June 15, 1897, the wooden structures on Ellis Island were razed in a fire of unknown origin. While there were no casualties, the wooden buildings had completely burned down after two hours, and all immigration records from 1855 had been destroyed.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1897/06/15/archives/fire-on-ellis-island-it-broke-out-shortly-after-midnight-in-the.html|title=Fire on Ellis Island; It Broke Out Shortly After Midnight in the Furnace of the Main Building|date=June 15, 1897|work=The New York Times|access-date=March 22, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Over five years of operation, the station had processed 1.5 million immigrants. === Second immigration station === ==== Design and construction ==== Following the fire, passenger arrivals were again processed at the Barge Office, which was soon unable to handle the large volume of immigrants.{{harvnb|ps=.|Unrau|1984|pp=215–216}} Within three days of the fire, the federal government made plans to build a new, fireproof immigration station.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=32}} Legislation to rebuild the station was approved on June 30, 1897,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1897/06/30/archives/to-restore-ellis-island-action-taken-by-the-treasury-department-and.html|title=To Restore Ellis Island; Action Taken by The Treasury Department and Congress.|date=June 30, 1897|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 6, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} and appropriations were made in mid-July.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=37}} By September, the Treasury's [[Office of the Supervising Architect for the U.S. Treasury|Supervising Architect]], [[James Knox Taylor]], opened an architecture competition to rebuild the immigration station. The competition was the second to be conducted under the [[Tarsney Act]] of 1893, which had permitted private architects to design federal buildings, rather than government architects in the Supervising Architect's office.{{harvnb|ps=.|Robins|Urbanelli|1993|p=15}}{{cite book | last=Lee | first=Antoinette J. | title=Architects to the Nation: The Rise and Decline of the Supervising Architect's Office | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2000 | isbn=978-0-19-535186-6 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hjDZz87NF8AC&pg=PA197 | access-date=December 11, 2019 | page=197}} The contest rules specified that a "main building with annexes" and a "hospital building", both made of fireproof materials, should be part of each nomination. Furthermore, the buildings had to be able to host a daily average of 1,000 and maximum of 4,000 immigrants.{{harvnb|ps=.|Robins|Urbanelli|1993|p=16}}[[File:Ellis Island in 1905.jpg|thumb|Second Ellis Island Immigration Station (opened 1900) as seen in 1905|alt=|left]]Several prominent architectural firms filed proposals,{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32307207/|title=New Landing Station|date=March 6, 1898|work=New York World|access-date=June 5, 2019|pages=11|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} and by December, it was announced that [[Edward Lippincott Tilton]] and [[William Boring|William A. Boring]] had won the competition.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1897/12/08/archives/ellis-island-plans-accepted.html|title=Ellis Island Plans Accepted|date=December 8, 1897|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 6, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Tilton and Boring's plan called for four new structures: a main building in the [[French Renaissance architecture|French Renaissance]] style, as well as the kitchen/laundry building, powerhouse, and the [[Ellis Island Immigrant Hospital|main hospital building]].{{Cite web|last1=Mausolf|first1=Lisa B.|title=Edward Lippincott Tilton: A Monograph on His Architectural Practice|url=https://www.nh.gov/nhdhr/publications/documents/etilton_monograph.pdf|year=2007|quote=|accessdate=September 28, 2011|last2=Hengen|first2=Elizabeth Durfee}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1898/01/28/archives/a-palace-for-immigrants-new-york-design-for-the-new-buildings-of.html|title=A Palace for Immigrants; New York Design for the New Buildings of the Ellis Island Station Accepted|date=January 28, 1898|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 6, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The plan also included the creation of a new island called island 2, upon which the hospital would be built, south of the existing island (now Ellis Island's north side). A construction contract was awarded to the R. H. Hood Company in August 1898, with the expectation that construction would be completed within a year,{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|pp=38–39}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y4_xrl_Y4h8C&pg=PA787-IA1|title=Bulletin of the Department of Labor|author=United States. Department of Labor|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office|year=1899|page=787–IA1|access-date=June 6, 2019|issue=v. 14–19}}{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32307907/|title=Contract Let To R.H. Hood|date=August 13, 1898|work=Brooklyn Standard-Union|access-date=June 5, 2019|pages=1|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} but the project encountered delays because of various obstacles and disagreements between the federal government and the Hood Company.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32307857/|title=Queer Management|date=June 5, 1899|work=Brooklyn Daily Eagle|access-date=June 5, 2019|pages=16|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} A separate contract to build the {{Convert|3.33|acre|ha|abbr=|adj=on}} island 2 had to be approved by the War Department because it was in New Jersey's waters; that contract was completed in December 1898.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=42}} The construction costs ultimately totaled $1.5 million. ==== Early expansions ==== The new immigration station opened on December 17, 1900, without ceremony. On that day, 2,251 immigrants were processed.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32308238/|title=Again at Ellis Island|date=December 17, 1900|work=New-York Tribune|access-date=June 5, 2019|pages=3|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}}{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=40}} Almost immediately, additional projects commenced to improve the main structure, including an entrance canopy, baggage conveyor, and railroad ticket office. The kitchen/laundry and powerhouse started construction in May 1900 and were completed by the end of 1901.{{harvnb|ps=.|Robins|Urbanelli|1993|p=37}} A ferry house was also built between islands 1 and 2 {{Circa|1901}}. The hospital, originally slated to be opened in 1899, was not completed until November 1901, mainly due to various funding delays and construction disputes.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=43}} The facilities proved barely able to handle the flood of immigrants that arrived, and as early as 1903, immigrants had to remain in their transatlantic boats for several days due to inspection backlogs.{{harvnb|ps=.|Historic Structure Report: The Main Building|1988|p=15}} Several wooden buildings were erected by 1903, including waiting rooms and a 700-bed barracks,{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=41}} and by 1904, over a million dollars' worth of improvements were proposed.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1904/01/16/archives/million-for-ellis-island-secretary-of-commerce-asks-that-sum-for.html|title=Million for Ellis Island; Secretary of Commerce Asks That Sum for Extensive Improvements.|date=January 16, 1904|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 6, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The hospital was expanded from 125 to 250 beds in February 1907, and a new psychopathic ward debuted in November of the same year. Also constructed was an administration building adjacent to the hospital.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=44}}{{harvnb|ps=.|Robins|Urbanelli|1993|p=25}} Immigration commissioner [[William Williams (commissioner)|William Williams]] made substantial changes to Ellis Island's operations, and during his tenure from 1902-1905 and 1909-1913, Ellis Island processed its peak number of immigrants. Williams also made changes to the island's appearance, adding plants and grading paths upon the once-barren landscape of Ellis Island.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|pp=45–46}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1903/07/12/archives/ellis-island-improved-commissioner-williamss-pleasing-landscape.html|title=Ellis Island Improved; Commissioner Williams's Pleasing Landscape Gardening|date=July 12, 1903|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 6, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Under Williams's supervision, a {{Convert|4.75|acre|ha|abbr=|adj=on}} third island was built to accommodate a proposed contagious-diseases ward, separated from existing facilities by {{Convert|200|ft|m|abbr=}} of water.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|pp=48–49}} Island 3, as it was called, was located to the south of island 2 and separated from that island by a now-infilled ferry basin. The government bought the underwater area for island 3 from New Jersey in 1904,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1904/12/18/archives/new-island-in-the-bay-government-buys-plot-under-water-adjoining.html|title=New Island in the Bay; Government Buys Plot Under Water Adjoining Ellis Island.|date=December 18, 1904|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 6, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} and a contract was awarded in April 1905. The islands were all connected via a cribwalk on their western sides (later covered with wood canopy), giving Ellis Island an overall "E"-shape.{{harvnb|ps=.|Robins|Urbanelli|1993|p=24}} Upon the completion of island 3 in 1906, Ellis Island covered {{Convert|20.25|acre|ha|abbr=}}.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=51}} A baggage and dormitory building was completed {{Circa|1908–1909}},{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=57|pp=57–58}} and the main hospital was expanded in 1909.{{harvnb|Stakely|2003|ps=.|pp=62–63}} Alterations were made to the registry building and dormitories as well, but even this was insufficient to accommodate the high volume of immigrants.{{harvnb|ps=.|Historic Structure Report: The Main Building|1988|p=16}} In 1911, Williams alleged that Congress had allocated too little for improvements to Ellis Island,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1911/07/11/archives/needs-of-ellis-island-commissioner-williams-says-congress-gives-too.html|title=Needs of Ellis Island; Commissioner Williams Says Congress Gives Too Little Money for Improvements.|date=July 11, 1911|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 7, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} even though the improvement budget that year was $868,000.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2764047/|title=14,500 Aliens Sent From Ellis Island|date=November 13, 1911|work=Brooklyn Daily Eagle|access-date=June 5, 2019|pages=7|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} [[File:Ellis Island - Great Hall.JPG|thumb|The main building's registry room]] Additional improvements and routine maintenance work were completed in the early 1910s. A greenhouse was built in 1910,{{harvnb|ps=.|Robins|Urbanelli|1993|p=70}} and the contagious-diseases ward on island 3 opened the following June.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=65}} In addition, the incinerator was replaced in 1911, and a recreation center operated by the [[American Red Cross]] was also built on island 2 by 1915. These facilities generally followed the design set by Tilton and Boring. When the [[Black Tom explosion]] occurred on Black Tom Island in 1916, the complex suffered moderate damage; though all immigrants were evacuated safely, the main building's roof collapsed, and windows were broken. The main building's roof was replaced with a [[Guastavino tile|Guastavino-tiled]] arched ceiling by 1918.{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/articles/black-tom-wwi.htm|title=Domestic Sabotage: The Explosion at Black Tom Island (U.S. National Park Service)|date=July 30, 1916|website=NPS.gov Homepage (U.S. National Park Service)|access-date=June 7, 2019}}{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24361048/|title=$45,000,000 Loss From Explosion In Wide Radius|date=July 31, 1916|work=New-York Tribune|access-date=June 5, 2019|pages=3|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}}{{harvnb|ps=.|Historic Structure Report: The Main Building|1988|p=17}} The immigration station was temporarily closed during [[World War I]] in 1917-1919, during which the facilities were used as a jail for suspected enemy combatants, and later as a treatment center for wounded American soldiers. Immigration inspections were conducted aboard ships or at docks.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1918/02/24/archives/ellis-island-war-hospital.html|title=Ellis Island War Hospital|date=February 24, 1918|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 7, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} During the war, immigration processing at Ellis Island declined by 97%, from 878,000 immigrants per year in 1914 to 26,000 per year in 1919.{{harvnb|ps=.|Unrau|1984|pp=734–735}} Ellis Island's immigration station was reopened in 1920, and processing had rebounded to 560,000 immigrants per year by 1921.{{harvnb|ps=.|Historic Structure Report: The Main Building|1988|p=18}} There were still ample complaints about the inadequate condition of Ellis Island's facilities.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1920/12/06/archives/plea-to-cure-evils-at-ellis-island-enlarged-buildings-and-larger.html|title=Plea To Cure Evils At Ellis Island; Enlarged Buildings and Larger Staff Asked to Handle Immigrants|date=December 6, 1920|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 7, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{cite news|url=|title=Getting the Right Start on the Road to Citizenship; Americanization's First Opportunity Is At Ellis Island|last=Pitney|first=Fred B.|date=August 15, 1920|work=New-York Tribune|pages=[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32376856/ 51], [https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32376971/ 52]|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} However, despite a request for $5.6 million in appropriations in 1921,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1921/01/15/archives/asks-5600000-for-ellis-island.html|title=Asks $5,600,000 for Ellis Island.|date=January 15, 1921|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 7, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} aid was slow to materialize, and initial improvement work was restricted to smaller projects such as the infilling of the basin between islands 2 and 3.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=75}} Other improvements included rearranging features such as staircases to improve pedestrian flow. These projects were supported by president [[Calvin Coolidge]], who in 1924 requested that Congress approve $300,000 in appropriations for the island.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1924/01/23/archives/300000-asked-for-ellis-island-president-transmits-to-congress-the.html|title=$300,000 Asked for Ellis Island; President Transmits to Congress the Budget Director's Items to Remedy Conditions.|date=January 23, 1924|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 7, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The allocations were not received until the late 1920s. ==== Conversion to detention center ==== [[File:Radicals awaiting deportation.jpg|thumb|right|[[Political radicalism|Radicals]] awaiting deportation, 1920]] With the passing of the [[Emergency Quota Act]] of 1921, the number of immigrants being allowed into the United States declined greatly, ending the era of mass immigration.{{Cite web|url=http://www.history.com/topics/ellis-island|title=Ellis Island - Facts & Summary - HISTORY.com|website=HISTORY.com|access-date=November 17, 2016}} Following the [[Immigration Act of 1924]], strict immigration quotas were enacted, and Ellis Island was downgraded from a primary inspection center to an immigrant-detention center, hosting only those that were to be detained or deported (see {{Section link||Mass detentions and deportations}}).{{harvnb|ps=.|Historic Structure Report: The Main Building|1988|p=19}}{{Cite journal|last=Jaynes|first=Gregory|title=American Scene: From Ellis Island to Lax|journal=TIME|date=July 8, 1985|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,959576-4,00.html | access-date=June 11, 2019}} Final inspections were now instead conducted on board ships in New York Harbor. The [[Wall Street Crash of 1929]] further decreased immigration, as people were now discouraged from immigrating to the U.S. Because of the resulting decline in patient counts, the hospital closed in 1930.{{cite news|url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/10/26/ellis-islands-forgotten-hospital/|title=Ellis Island's Forgotten Hospital|last=Chan|first=Sewell|date=October 26, 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=December 27, 2011|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{cite web|last=Haberman|first=Clyde|title=The Other Ellis Island|website=The New York Times|date=March 22, 1998|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/22/magazine/the-other-ellis-island.html | access-date=June 11, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/remembering-the-dark-side-of-ellis-island/|title=Remembering The Dark Side Of Ellis Island|last=Johnson|first=Caitlin|date=June 1, 2007|website=CBS News|access-date=June 5, 2019}} [[Edward Corsi]], who himself was an immigrant, became Ellis Island commissioner in 1931 and commenced an improvement program for the island. The initial improvements were utilitarian, focusing on such aspects as sewage, incineration, and power generation.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|pp=78–79}}{{harvnb|ps=.|Historic Structure Report: The Main Building|1988|pp=20–21}} In 1933, a federal committee led by the [[United States Secretary of Labor|Secretary of Labor]], [[Frances Perkins]], was established to determine what operations and facilities needed improvement.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1933/06/23/archives/committee-named-on-ellis-island-miss-perkins-appoints-42-to.html|title=Committee Named on Ellis Island; Miss Perkins Appoints 42 to Investigate Conditions Facing Immigrants|date=June 23, 1933|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 7, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The committee's report, released in 1934, suggested the construction of a new class-segregated immigration building, recreation center, ferry house, verandas, and doctors/nurses' quarters, as well as the installation of a new seawall around the island.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=80}}{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32378881/|title=3 New Buildings To Be Erected For Ellis Island Aliens|date=April 1, 1934|work=New York Daily News|access-date=June 5, 2019|pages=36|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}}{{harvnb|ps=.|Robins|Urbanelli|1993|pp=26–27}} These works were undertaken using [[Public Works Administration]] funding and [[Works Progress Administration]] labor, and were completed by the late 1930s. As part of the project, the surgeon's house and recreation center were demolished, and [[Edward Laning]] commissioned some murals for the island's buildings.{{harvnb|ps=.|Unrau|1984|pp=952–953}} Other improvements included the demolition of the greenhouse, the completion of the infilling of the basin between islands 2 and 3, and various landscaping activities such as the installation of walkways and plants.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|pp=87–88}} However, because of the steep decline in immigration, the immigration building went underused for several years, and it started to deteriorate. With the start of [[World War II]] in 1939, Ellis Island was again utilized by the military, this time being used as a [[United States Coast Guard]] base.{{harvnb|ps=.|Unrau|1984|pp=822–824}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1939/10/31/archives/ellis-island-to-get-coast-guard.html|title=Ellis Island to Get Coast Guard|date=October 31, 1939|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 7, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=83}} As during World War I, the facilities were used to detain enemy soldiers in addition to immigrants, and the hospital was used for treating injured American soldiers. So many combatants were detained at Ellis Island that administrative offices were moved to mainland Manhattan in 1943, and Ellis Island was used solely for detainment.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1943/04/11/archives/immigration-work-is-consolidated-here-ellis-island-solely-for.html|title=Immigration Work Is Consolidated Here; Ellis Island Solely for Custody of Aliens|date=April 11, 1943|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 7, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} By 1947, shortly after the end of World War II, there were proposals to close Ellis Island due to the massive expenses needed for the upkeep of a relatively small detention center.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32379183/|title=Economy Plan May Close Ellis Island|date=June 16, 1947|work=Ithaca Journal|access-date=June 5, 2019|pages=9|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} The hospital was closed in 1950-1951 by the [[United States Public Health Service]], and by the early 1950s, there were only 30 to 40 detainees left on the island.{{harvnb|ps=.|Stakely|2003|p=92}}{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32421643/|title=U.S. Will Move All Ellis Island Immigration Facilities to Manhattan|date=July 29, 1954|work=Press and Sun-Bulletin|access-date=June 5, 2019|location=Binghamton, NY|pages=4|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} The island's closure was announced in mid-1954, when the federal government announced that it would construct a replacement facility on Manhattan.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1954/06/03/archives/ellis-island-to-go-as-alien-station-service-now-needs-smaller.html|title=Ellis Island to Go as Alien Station; Service Now Needs Smaller Quarters|date=June 3, 1954|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 7, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Ellis Island closed on November 12, 1954, with the departure of its last detainee, Norwegian merchant seaman Arne Peterssen.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32422249/|title=Ellis Island Becomes Lonely Way Station for the Seagulls|date=November 12, 1954|work=The Herald-News|access-date=June 5, 2019|location=Passaic, NJ|pages=7|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1954/11/13/archives/ellis-island-ends-alien-processing-last-detained-person-leaves.html|title=Ellis Island Ends Alien Processing; Last Detained Person Leaves|date=November 13, 1954|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 7, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{Cite web|url=https://time.com/3563179/ellis-island/|title=How Ellis Island Changed Before It Closed|website=Time|language=en|access-date=June 7, 2019}} At the time, it was estimated that the government would save $900,000 a year from closing the island. The ferryboat ''Ellis Island'', which had operated since 1904, stopped operating two weeks later.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1954/11/30/archives/ellis-island-boat-makes-last-trip-after-million-miles-on-harbor-run.html|title=Ellis Island Boat Makes Last Trip After Million Miles on Harbor Run|date=November 30, 1954|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 8, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} === Post-closure === ==== Initial redevelopment plans ==== [[File:Ellis Island Complex.jpg|thumb|Seen from east. From left to right: contagious diseases ward; lawn; hospital; ferry basin; main building, kitchen, dormitory, and immigration building]] After the immigration station closed, the buildings fell into disrepair and were abandoned,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1964/07/16/archives/once-teeming-ellis-island-bleak-and-crumbling-is-now-the-home-of-a.html|title=Once Teeming Ellis Island, Bleak and Crumbling, Is Now the Home of a Lone Black Dog|date=July 16, 1964|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 7, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} and the [[General Services Administration]] (GSA) took over the island in March 1955. The GSA wanted to sell off the island as "surplus property"{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/27461272/|title=Shrine for Sale|date=December 2, 1962|work=New York Daily News|access-date=June 5, 2019|pages=204|via=newspapers.com {{open access}}}} and contemplated several options, including selling the island back to the city of New York{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1957/11/17/archives/gift-of-ellis-island-to-city-now-hinted-ellis-island-gift-to-city.html|title=Gift of Ellis Island To City Now Hinted|date=November 17, 1957|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 7, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} or auctioning it to a private buyer.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1956/09/14/archives/ellis-island-will-be-sold-at-auction-u-s-selling-haven-of-migration.html|title=Ellis Island Will Be Sold at Auction; U. S. Selling Haven of Migration Days for Private Use|last=Lawn|first=Victor H.|date=September 14, 1956|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 7, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} In 1959, real estate developer [[Sol Atlas]] unsuccessfully bid for the island, with plans to turn it into a $55 million resort with a hotel, marina, music shell, tennis courts, swimming pools, and skating rinks.{{Cite web|url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/the-1958-plan-to-turn-ellis-island-into-a-vacation-resort-124287872/|title=The 1958 Plan to Turn Ellis Island Into a Vacation Resort|last=Novak|first=Matt|date=June 18, 2012|website=Smithsonian|language=en|access-date=June 8, 2019}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1973/07/31/archives/sol-atlas-dies-builder-was-66-expert-on-shopping-centers-also.html|title=Sol Atlas Dies; Builder Was 66|date=July 31, 1973|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 8, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The same year, [[Frank Lloyd Wright]] designed the $100 million "Key Project",{{Efn|The name "Key Project" is a reference to how "the island represented the key to freedom and opportunity for so many."|name=|group=}} which included housing, hotels, and large domes along the edges.
